title: Climb
subtitle: Cost: +1ft per 1ft
description: Climbing is difficult terrain, costing 1 extra foot of movement for every foot climbed unless you have a climb speed.

bullets.content: Vertical movement is a key part of exploration. Unless a creature is a natural climber, doing so is slow and functions as difficult terrain, effectively costing double movement.

items: Each foot of movement spent climbing costs 1 extra foot. So, moving 5 feet up a wall costs 10 feet of your speed.
A creature with a climbing speed ignores this extra cost.
The DM might require a Strength (Athletics) check for a particularly difficult or slippery surface.

bullets.content: Remember this cost, as it means a creature with a 30-foot speed can climb a maximum of 15 feet in a turn without taking the Dash action.

title: Crawl
subtitle: Cost: +1ft per 1ft
description: While prone, your only movement option is to crawl, which costs 1 extra foot of movement for every foot moved.

bullets.content: Crawling is the slow movement you are restricted to while in the Prone condition. It functions as difficult terrain, representing the struggle to move along the ground.

items: Each foot of movement spent crawling costs 1 extra foot.
Crawling is the only way to move while you have the Prone condition, unless you first use half your movement to stand up.

bullets.content: To regain your full speed, you must first spend half your total movement to stand up, which ends the prone condition and is usually a more efficient option.

title: Difficult Terrain
subtitle: Cost modifier: +1ft per 1ft
description: Moving through areas like rubble, snow, or undergrowth costs double movement, effectively halving your speed.

bullets.content: Difficult terrain is one of the most common environmental factors in combat, making positioning and movement a tactical challenge. For every 1 foot you move in difficult terrain, you must spend 1 extra foot of movement.

items: Examples include low furniture, rubble, undergrowth, steep stairs, snow, and shallow bogs.
The space of another creature, whether hostile or not, is also difficult terrain.
Some features, like the Ranger's Natural Explorer, allow you to ignore the effects of nonmagical difficult terrain.

bullets.content: This means a 5-foot step into rubble costs 10 feet of your movement. This extra cost applies to all movement types, including walking, climbing, and swimming.

title: Drop Prone
subtitle: Cost: 0ft
description: You can drop to the ground at any point on your turn without using any of your speed.

bullets.content: This is a free and instantaneous way to change your stance. It's often used defensively to make yourself a harder target for ranged attacks, though it comes with tactical trade-offs.

items: Dropping prone costs no part of your speed, action, or reaction.
It can be done at any time during your turn.
Doing so gives you the Prone condition.

bullets.content: While being prone imposes disadvantage on ranged attackers, it grants advantage to melee attackers within 5 feet, so use this tactic wisely.

title: Grapple Move
subtitle: Modifier: speed halved
description: When you move while grappling another creature, your speed is halved unless the creature is two or more sizes smaller.

bullets.content: Once you have a creature grappled, you can forcibly move them. This comes at a cost to your own speed, representing the difficulty of dragging an unwilling foe.

items: When you move, you can drag or carry the grappled creature with you.
Your speed is halved for the turn, unless the creature is two or more sizes smaller than you.
This penalty applies to your total speed for the turn, and it stacks with difficult terrain.

bullets.content: For example, with a 30ft speed, grappling halves it to 15ft. Moving 5ft through difficult terrain would then cost 10ft of that 15ft pool, leaving you with only 5ft of movement.

title: High Jump
subtitle: Height: 3 + STR MOD feet
description: After moving at least 10 feet, you can jump vertically a number of feet equal to 3 + your Strength modifier.

bullets.content: Your high jump capability determines the maximum height you can clear, and each foot jumped costs a foot of movement. The distance depends on whether you get a running start.

items: A running high jump, which requires moving at least 10 feet on foot immediately before, allows you to jump a height of 3 + your Strength modifier in feet.
A standing high jump is only half that distance.
You can extend your arms half your height above yourself during the jump to reach higher ledges.
Each foot you clear costs a foot of movement.

bullets.content: For example, a character with 16 Strength (+3 mod) can make a running high jump of 6 feet, allowing them to leap onto a crate or over a low wall.

title: Long Jump
subtitle: Distance: STR score in feet
description: After moving at least 10 feet, you can jump horizontally a number of feet up to your Strength score.

bullets.content: Your long jump capability determines the maximum distance you can cross over a gap, and each foot jumped costs a foot of movement. The distance depends on whether you get a running start.

items: A running long jump, which requires moving at least 10 feet on foot immediately before, allows you to jump a distance up to your Strength score in feet.
A standing long jump is only half that distance.
Each foot you clear costs a foot of movement.
The DM may require a DC 10 Strength (Athletics) check to clear a low obstacle during the jump.

bullets.content: A character with a Strength score of 14 can make a running long jump up to 14 feet to cross a chasm, provided they have 14 feet of movement to spend.

title: Mount/Dismount
subtitle: Cost: half movement speed
description: Once on your turn, you can mount or dismount a creature by spending movement equal to half your speed.

bullets.content: Mounting a willing creature that is at least one size larger than you is a common way to increase travel speed. The cost to do so is part of your move, and there are risks involved if your mount is forcibly moved or knocked down.

items: Mounting or dismounting costs an amount of movement equal to half your speed. For example, if your speed is 30 feet, you must spend 15 feet of movement.
If an effect moves your mount against its will, you must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw or fall off, landing prone within 5 feet of it.
If your mount is knocked prone, you can use your reaction to dismount as it falls. Otherwise, you are dismounted and fall prone.

bullets.content: This cost is a flat rate. With a 30-foot speed, you must spend 15 feet of movement to mount your horse, leaving you with 15 feet remaining to move on your own that turn if you wish.

title: Move
subtitle: Cost: 1ft per 1ft
description: On your turn, you can move a distance up to your speed, breaking up this movement however you wish.

bullets.content: Movement is a resource, not an action. You have a pool of movement on your turn equal to your speed, which you can spend in any increment. You can also interact with other creatures' spaces in specific ways.

items: You can break up your movement during your turn, using some of your speed before and after your action.
You can move through a nonhostile creature's space. You can only move through a hostile creature's space if it is at least two sizes larger or smaller than you.
Another creature's space is always difficult terrain for you.
You can't willingly end your move in another creature's space.

bullets.content: This flexibility is key to combat, allowing you to move from cover, attack, and then return to cover, all on the same turn.

title: Squeezing
subtitle: Move through a smaller space
description: You can move through a space one size category smaller than you, but you suffer significant penalties while doing so.

bullets.content: Squeezing allows passage through tight areas, but it comes at a major cost to both your movement and your combat effectiveness, making you slow and vulnerable.

items: While squeezing, every foot of movement costs 1 extra foot (as if in difficult terrain).
You have disadvantage on attack rolls and Dexterity saving throws.
Attack rolls against you have advantage.

bullets.content: For example, a Medium creature can squeeze through a narrow passage meant for a Small creature, but they will be an easy target for any enemies waiting on the other side.

title: Stand Up
subtitle: Cost: half movement speed
description: While prone, you can stand up by using movement equal to half your speed.

bullets.content: Rising from a prone position is a costly but necessary part of recovering in a fight. The cost is a flat half of your total speed, not your remaining speed for the turn.

items: Standing up costs half of your total speed. For a creature with 30 feet of speed, it costs 15 feet of movement.
This cost is deducted from your available movement for the turn.
You can't stand up if you don't have enough movement left or if your speed is 0.

bullets.content: This fixed cost means that even if you only have 1 foot of movement remaining, you cannot stand up if your speed is 30, as the cost is 15 feet.

title: Swim
subtitle: Cost: +1ft per 1ft
description: Swimming is difficult terrain, costing 1 extra foot of movement for every foot swam unless you have a swim speed.

bullets.content: Moving through water can be slow and challenging for land-based creatures. Unless a creature is naturally aquatic, swimming costs double movement as it is treated as difficult terrain.

items: Each foot of movement spent swimming costs 1 extra foot. So, moving 5 feet through water costs 10 feet of your speed.
A creature with a swimming speed ignores this extra cost.
The DM might require a Strength (Athletics) check for rough water or strong currents.

bullets.content: This rule, combined with the rules for underwater combat, makes fighting in water a distinct and dangerous tactical challenge.

title: Travel Pace
subtitle: Traveling for an hour or more
description: When traveling overland, your group's pace determines how far you move and how aware you are of your surroundings.

bullets.content: These rules govern long-distance travel, abstracting movement into hours and days. The pace you choose creates a trade-off between speed and awareness.

Forced March: For each additional hour of travel beyond 8 hours in a day, a character must make a Constitution saving throw at the end of the hour. The DC is 10 + 1 for each hour past 8. On a failed save, a character suffers one level of exhaustion.
These distances assume relatively simple terrain like plains or roads. The DM can halve these distances for difficult terrain like dense forests or mountains.
